div.head:
Embleme 48. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The King falls sicke by drinking water, and is restored to health
by Physicians.

lg.l: In wealth nor people dos the King delight,
Soe much as to have water brought in sight.
Cup after cup hee drinks, growes swelld and wanne
Where finding art by various means essayd,
His health restord and tumor was allayd.

div.head: Discourse 48.
div.ab:
Xerxes that most potent King of Persia leading his army through dry-
and rugged places in hott weather, being thirsty, refused not a draught-
of muddy water offered by a souldier, but dranke most freely, and rewarded
him that brought it very amply. And indeed if a man at this very time
(as some of the latest historians affirme) travell through the borders of
Persia, it is sayd that fountains of sweet water are very rarely found,
standing waters being brackish, and the Soyle itselfe in the surface-
yeilding much saltnesse: After the same manner the King, which the
Philosophers have made mention of being perplexed with thirst, com
manded plenty of sweet water to be brought him, of which hee dranke
his fill; as if manifest to any man by the Allegory of Merlinus. The
cure of the sicke and discoloured King is undertaken by severall Physi
tians: The Ã†gyptians administring their medicines stirred the humors
being yet crude, which Hippocrates affirms ought to be purged being-
first concocted, unlesse they be fluxible and uncertaine: For then they
must be forthwith expelled, that they may not peradventure make an
assault upon the more noble parts or bowells. Hereupon dangerous Symp
toms, such as Hipothymy and Syncope happened to the King, but the Phy
sicians of Alexandria coming last of all, and esteemed more successfull
in a chronicke disease, restored the King to his former health. It is well-
worth while to cure soe great a King, who being made sound extends a
liberall hand and a serene aspect to his Physician. Wee have read that-
many mens cures have been very nobly rewarded by severall Kings, as-
that of Domocides by Polycrates a tyrant of Samos with two talents, of
Erasiscratus (who, as Pliny writes, was Schollar of Chrysippus, begotten-
upon the daughter of Aristotle) for curing King Antiochus being sicke
for the love of his Stepmother Stratonice, with a hundred talents by his
Sonne Ptolemy, of Jacob Cocterius, Physician of Lewis the 2d King of-
France, from whome hee receivd four thousand Crowns every moneth as
a stipend, and other later wee make noe mention of; but the cure of
this King is recompensed with yet a farre greater gratuity or reward. For
thus say Hermes and Geber in the Rosary: Hee that hath once com
pleted this art, if hee should live ten hundred thousand years, and-
every day feed four thousand men, would not want. This Senior con
firms, saying: Hee that hath that stone, whereof the Elixir is made
is soe rich, as hee that hath fire, can give fire, to whome hee will, and-
when hee will, and as much as hee will without his owne detriment or want.
The father of Democritus was soe rich, that hee gave a feast to the-
army of Xerxes, and Pythius a man exceding wealthy offered to the-
same pay for his whole army, and victuall for five moneths, provided-
that the youngest of his five sonns, which was the comfort of his old-
age, might be permitted to stay at home, and not be constraind to goe-
Discourse 48.
into the Kings army, but the barbarous King taking the petition of Pythius
most unworthily, comanded his younger sonne to be cutt in two peices,-
and fastened to stakes on both sides the high way, by which his whole ar
my was to passe, as Sabellicus observes in booke 2. Ennead 3. but the riches
of these men are nothing to the riches of our King, which are without-
dimension and number. Being cured and freed from the waters all the
Kings, and Potentates of other regions did honour and fear him: And when
they were willing to see any of his wonderfull works, they putt one-
ounce of Mercury well washd in a crucible, and cast thereupon (as it were
one graine of Millet seed) of his nayls, or of his harre or blood, and-
blowd gently with coales, they let it coole with them, and found such a
stone as I know. This is hee, whome Count Bernhard mentioneth, that-
gives to his six courtiers soe much of his kingdome, as hee himselfe possesseth,
provided they waite, till hee recover youth in the bath, and be adorned-
with various garments, namely, a blacke breast=plate, a white shirt, and
purple blood; for then hee promiseth to give some of his blood to every
one, and make them partakers of his riches. . . . . . . .
